articles.headline: Seeking North Korea Deal, Trump Seems Willing to Ease U.S. Demands
articles.snippet: Arriving in Hanoi for a second meeting with Kim Jong-un, President Trump sounds as if he is retreating on his ambition to eliminate the North’s nuclear arsenal.
articles.abstract: Arriving in Hanoi for a second meeting with Kim Jong-un, President Trump sounds as if he is retreating on his ambition to eliminate the North’s nuclear arsenal.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — When he vowed to “solve” the North Korea problem just before his inauguration two years ago, President Trump made clear he meant eliminating its nuclear arsenal.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: United Methodists Tighten Ban on Same-Sex Marriage and Gay Clergy
articles.snippet: The decision, opposed by progressive members of the church and gay and lesbian pastors, could ultimately splinter the church.
articles.abstract: The decision, opposed by progressive members of the church and gay and lesbian pastors, could ultimately splinter the church.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The United Methodist Church on Tuesday voted to strengthen its ban on gay and lesbian clergy and same-sex marriages, a decision that could split the nation’s second-largest Protestant church.
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: House Votes to Block Trump’s National Emergency Declaration About the Border
articles.snippet: The House easily voted on Tuesday to block President Trump’s declaration of a national emergency at the Mexican border, seeking to stop the diversion of funds to his wall.
articles.abstract: The House easily voted on Tuesday to block President Trump’s declaration of a national emergency at the Mexican border, seeking to stop the diversion of funds to his wall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Tuesday to overturn President Trump’s declaration of a national emergency on the Mexican border, with just 13 Republicans joining Democrats to try to block his effort to divert funding to a border wall without congressional approval.

articles.headline: Trump Undermines Top Trade Adviser as He Pushes for China Deal
articles.snippet: Robert Lighthizer, the United States trade representative, must defend a trade pact that is shaping up to be less ambitious than he might once have hoped.
articles.abstract: Robert Lighthizer, the United States trade representative, must defend a trade pact that is shaping up to be less ambitious than he might once have hoped.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has signaled that he is moving toward peace with China in a trade standoff that has rattled markets and businesses globally. But as he backs off his threat to impose higher tariffs, the president’s relationship with his own trade negotiator is now showing signs of strain.

articles.headline: SALT Limit Is Hitting 11 Million Tax Returns, Audit Finds
articles.snippet: The Treasury report also shows the level of attention that high-ranking administration officials paid to a controversial regulation from the new tax law.
articles.abstract: The Treasury report also shows the level of attention that high-ranking administration officials paid to a controversial regulation from the new tax law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to cap a popular tax break will hit 11 million filers this year, as they can no longer deduct more than $10,000 in state and local taxes from their federal income taxes.

articles.headline: Pakistani Military Says It Downed Two Indian Warplanes, Capturing Pilot
articles.snippet: Hostilities grow with a second day of airstrikes and the first planes downed. Other countries call for the nuclear-armed rivals to show restraint.
articles.abstract: Hostilities grow with a second day of airstrikes and the first planes downed. Other countries call for the nuclear-armed rivals to show restraint.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Pakistan said Wednesday that it downed two Indian fighter jets and captured a pilot, escalating hostilities between the nuclear-armed neighbors a day after Indian warplanes struck inside Pakistani territory for the first time in five decades.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: China Shifts, and Detroit’s Big Bet Goes Sour
articles.snippet: Chrysler, Ford and General Motors saw a booming Chinese driving culture and cheap labor. Now the market is slowing, competition is rising and the Trump administration wants limits.
articles.abstract: Chrysler, Ford and General Motors saw a booming Chinese driving culture and cheap labor. Now the market is slowing, competition is rising and the Trump administration wants limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHONGQING, China — For Detroit, China once meant opportunity. The country’s growing ranks of drivers bought cars by the millions. Its cheap labor gave American automakers dreams of someday exporting their Chinese-made cars to the United States. The Big Three bet billions of dollars there.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Ailin Tang
